properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds gusting between 90 and 100 km/h continue in the Jasper region and by noon in the Banff region, including the HWY 93 corridor. These strong winds will begin to diminish late this evening, however winds gusting near 70 km/h can be expected to persist into Monday. HWY 93: snowfall is expected along the southern section of Highway 93 today, intensifying this evening and persisting into Monday evening. This snowfall combined with strong gusty winds will reduce visibility at times in blowing snow. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-22T10:26:41-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for late tonight and early Monday morning. An area of snow is forecast to move across the area later tonight through early Monday morning. The snow will become heavy at times resulting in areas of poor visibility. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm can be expected by the time the snow tapers to periods of light snow or flurries later Monday morning. Motorists are advised to exercise caution and alter their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Monday. An area of snow is forecast to move across the area beginning late tonight through Monday. The snow will become heavy at times Monday morning, and will likely result in poor visibility. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm can be expected by the time the snow comes to an end Monday afternoon or Monday evening. Areas of higher elevation may see even higher amounts. The Monday morning commute will likely be impacted and motorists are advised to exercise caution and alter their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow changing to heavy rain with the potential for heavy snow at the summit for tonight. A frontal system laden with subtropical moisture will move across southern B.C. today through Monday morning bringing a messy mix of rain on top of snow today and the possibility of heavy wet snow at the summit tonight into Monday morning. The initial warm front will raise snow levels today with snow still falling on the upper elevations of the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 via Allison Pass. By tonight, the warm airmass will be over southern B.C. with snow levels near or slightly above the Coquihalla Summit and Allison Pass. Rain will fall over most of the highway with wet snow or rain mixed with snow near at summit. As the cold front approaches tonight, precipitation rates will intensify and thus there is potential for snow levels to drop just below the summit or pass levels. Total snow accumulations near 25 cm can be expected near the summit level by Monday morning. Motorists are advised to be aware of changing weather and road conditions due to fluctuating snow levels and precipitation intensity during this period. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-22T05:17:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-21T13:18:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1071124344.2021
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm tonight. A frontal system laden with subtropical moisture will move across B.C. South Coast tonight bringing rain to the region. Over Howe Sound and eastern sections of Lower Fraser Valley, steady rain will become heavy this evening. Squamish area has received over 42 mm rain since Saturday evening. Hope area is reporting 32 mm last 24 hours. Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected before the heavy rain tapers off overnight over Howe Sound and early Monday morning over eastern Fraser Valley. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A frontal system laden with subtropical moisture continues to bring snow to parts of the Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass section. As snow levels hover around 1200 metres tonight, rain will fall over most of the highway with snow expected at higher elevations. The snow is forecast to intensify tonight and continue throughout Monday with accumulations possibly reaching 35 cm by Monday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
